sen.j: 御簾中（ごれんじゅう）はかつて日本で貴人の正妻を指して言った敬称のこと。
sen.e: Gorenju refers to a title of honor which used to indicate a legal wife of aristocrat in Japan.
sen.cmt: 御簾中「ごれんちゅう」とも読むようです。[http://kotobank.jp/word/%E5%BE%A1%E7%B0%BE%E4%B8%AD]
sen.e: Gorenju was a title of honor used to indicate a legal wife of an aristocrat in Japan.
sen.cmt: fixed grammar
sen.e: Gorenju was a title of honor used to indicate a legal wife of an aristocrat in Japan.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 江戸時代以降、江戸幕府により使用に厳しい制限をされるようになった。
sen.e: After the Edo Period, its use was strictly limited by the Edo shogunate.
After the Edo Period, the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) put strict limitations on the use of the term.
sen.cmt: changed "Edo shogunate" to "Edo bakufu" and added description to follow the word list; fixed grammar to read more naturally
sen.e: After the Edo period, the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) put strict limitations on the use of the term.
sen.cmt: Periodの頭文字を小文字に変更

sen.j: 奈良時代以前には「御簾中」という言葉は存在していなかった。
sen.e: Before the Nara Period, the term 'Gorenju' had not existed.
The term "Gorenju" had not existed before the Nara Period.
sen.cmt: rearranged sentence to read more naturally
sen.e: The term 'Gorenju' had not existed before the Nara period.
sen.cmt: Periodの頭文字を小文字に変更、シングルクォーテーションに変更

sen.j: 平安時代中期以降、貴族の女性は親兄弟といえどもみだりに異性に顔を見せてはいけない、という習慣が定着した。
sen.e: After the mid Heian Period, a custom that noble women were not supposed to show their face to the opposite sex even though he was their father or brother became conventional, and they met people across sudare (bamboo screen) or kicho (screen), which is regarded as its origin.

From the mid-Heian Period, it was an established custom for noble women to not show their faces to the opposite sex, even if it was their father or brother. It is believed that the etymology of "Gorenju" came from the custom of women meeting people on opposite sides of a sudare (bamboo screen) or kicho (screen).
sen.cmt: added hyphen in "Mid-Heian"; split into two sentences; changed "origin" to "etymology" for "語源"; fixed grammar
sen.e: From the mid-Heian Period, it was an established custom for noble women not to show their faces to the opposite sex, even if it was their father or brother.
sen.cmt: to not show→not to showに修正「一原文一訳文の例外対処」

sen.j: 簾や几帳を隔てて人に面会したことが語源と考えられる。
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: It is believed that the etymology of 'Gorenju' came from the custom of women meeting people on opposite sides of a sudare (bamboo screen) or kicho (screen).
sen.cmt: シングルクォーテーションに変更「一原文一訳文の例外対処」

sen.j: ただし、平安時代の文献では貴人の正妻を指して「御簾中」と書いた物は存在していない。
sen.e: However, there is no literary work of the Heian Period, referring to a legal wife of aristocrat as 'Gorenju.'
There is no literary work from the Heian period, however, that refers to a legal wife of an aristrocrat as a "Gorenju."
sen.cmt: moved position of "however" to the middle of the sentence; fixed grammar
sen.e: There is no literary work from the Heian period, however, that refers to a legal wife of an aristrocrat as a 'Gorenju.'

sen.j: 戦国時代 (日本)には戦国大名の夫人を指して「御簾中」と記述した文書が見受けられる。
sen.e: Documents of the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States), referring to a wife of a warring lord as 'Gorenju' are found.

On the other hand, there have been documents found from the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States) where the wife of Sengoku daimyo (Japanese territorial lord in the Sengoku period) was referred to as a "Gorenju."
sen.cmt: added "On the other hand" to make a contrast with the last paragraph; changed "warring lord" to "Sengoku daimyo" and added description from the word list; fixed grammar
sen.e: On the other hand, there have been documents found from the Sengoku period (period of Warring States) where the wife of Sengoku daimyo (Japanese territorial lord in the Sengoku period) was referred to as a 'Gorenju.'
sen.cmt: Periodの頭文字を小文字に変更、シングルクォーテーションに変更

sen.j: 江戸幕府は大名統制策の一環として、その正室の呼称すらランク付けを行った。
sen.e: The Edo shogunate ranked even the naming of the legal wives as part of the daimyo (Japanese feudal lord) control.
The Edo bakufu went so far as to put the naming of a legal wife under the control of the daimyo (Japanese feudal lord).
sen.cmt: changed "shogunate" to "bakufu" to follow the word list; fixed grammar to read more understandably
sen.e: The Edo bakufu went so far as to put the naming of a legal wife under the control of the daimyo (Japanese feudal lord).
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 「御台所」が征夷大将軍の正室に限られたのは有名である。
sen.e: It is famous that the term 'Midaidokoro' was limited to the legal wife of Seii Taishogun (Barbarian Subduing Generalissimo).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の原則の例外対処
sen.e: It is well-known that the term "Midaidokoro" was limited to the legal wife of the Seii Taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians").

sen.cmt: 一部シングルクォーテーションに変更

sen.j: 同じように格式のある「御簾中」は将軍の世子と御三家の正室を呼ぶときのみに限定した。
sen.e: Likewise, the prestigious term 'Gorenju' was limited to referring the wives of Shogun's heirs and Gosanke (three privileged branches).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の原則の例外対処
sen.e: Similarly, the prestigious term "Gorenju" was limited to the wives of heirs to the Shogun and the Gosanke (three privileged branch families).

sen.j: ただし、後に徳川家斉の正室となった広大院の場合、立場が微妙であったためか当初は「御縁女様」と呼ばれている。
sen.e: However, Kodaiin, who later became the legal wife of Ienari TOKUGAWA was called 'Goenjosama' at first, perhaps because she was in a delicate position.

sen.j: 後に御三卿が誕生すると、御三卿の役割は御三家に匹敵するところから、御三卿の正室も「御簾中」と呼んだ。
sen.e: When Gosankyo (another three privileged branches) was formed later, the legal wives of Gosanke were also called 'Gorenju' because the roles of Gosankyo were equivalent to those of Gosanke.
Later on when Gosankyo (another three privileged branch families) was formed, the legal wives of Gosanke were also called "Gorenju" due to the roles of Gosankyo being equivalent to the Gosanke.

sen.j: ちなみに、それ以外の大名の正室は10万石以上が「御前様」でそれ以下は「奥方」であった。
sen.e: And the legal wives of other daimyo with ten 100,000 koku crop yields were called 'Gozensama,' and those with less than that 'Okugata.'
